questions.text: An infant delivered at full-term by normal vaginal delivery, presented with respiratory distress immediately after birth. Chest X-ray showed the following picture. What is the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The above X-ray chest shows intra-thoracic bowel shadows along with mediastinal shift suggestive of congenital diaphragmatic hernia.

The common clinical presentation is as follows:

  • Respiratory distress
  • Dextrocardia
  • Scaphoid abdomen

Prenatal diagnosis is done by ultrasonography. Lung-to-head ratio (LHR) is used to assess severity in patients with left-sided CDH. An LHR value of <1 is associated with a very poor prognosis, whereas an LHR >1.4 predicts a more favourable outcome.

Option A: Hyaline membrane disease is a syndrome in premature infants caused by developmental insufficiency of pulmonary surfactant production and structural immaturity in the lungs.

Option B: Meconium aspiration syndrome is the aspiration of meconium-stained amniotic fluid, which can occur before, during or immediately after birth. Meconium is the first intestinal discharge from newborns, a viscous, dark-green substance composed of intestinal epithelial cells, lanugo, mucus, and intestinal secretions.

Option D: During normal delivery, the compression of the rib cage while passing through the mother's vaginal canal helps to remove fluid from the lungs. However, newborns who are delivered via cesarean birth may have excess fluid in the lungs and therefore be hypoxic and develop transient tachypnea.

Related Pearl: Radiologic features of the major respiratory distress disorders in newborns

Congenital Diaphragmatic Hernia

  • Mediastinal shift
  • Bowel loops in the left hemithorax

 

Respiratory Distress Syndrome

  • Low lung volume
  • Symmetric ground-glass opacity (reticulogranular pattern)
  • Air bronchogram
  • White-out lung (severe disease)

Chest radiograph (A) on Day 2: shows reticulogranular opacities throughout both lungs with prominent air bronchograms. The cardiac silhouette is preserved and both lungs are hypoaerated.

Chest radiograph (B) on Day 9 (untreated): shows more severe changes. There is obliteration of the cardiac and diaphragmatic contours due to marked opacification, giving a complete ‘white out’ appearance

 Meconium Aspiration Syndrome

  • Hyperinflation
  • Patchy infiltrates
  • Coarse streaking

questions.text: Which of the following statements is false regarding congenital diaphragmatic hernia?

choices.text: Most CDH defects occur on the left side
Occurs due to failure of closure of the pleuroperitoneal canal in the developing fetus
Pulmonary hypoplasia and pulmonary hypertension significantly affects the prognosis
The posterolateral variant of this hernia is known as Morgagni hernia

questions.solution:
The posterolateral variant of congenital diaphragmatic hernia (CDH) is known as Bochdalek hernia while the anteromedian variant is called Morgagni hernia.

Congenital diaphragmatic hernia results from the failure of closure of the pleuroperitoneal canal in the developing fetus.

Typically in CDH, there is a left-sided posterolateral diaphragmatic defect allowing herniation of abdominal viscera into the chest. 80% of CDH develops on the left side.

The following sequence of events in CDH leads to the development of pulmonary hypoplasia.

Pulmonary hypertension and pulmonary hypoplasia are the most important prognostic factors in congenital diaphragmatic hernia.

Other poor prognostic indicators in CDH :

  • The presence of liver in the thoracic cavity 
  • Early respiratory distress, within 24 h after birth
  • Need for extracorporeal membrane oxygenation
  • Herniation to the contralateral lung (right-sided hernia)
  •  

Treatment of congenital diaphragmatic hernia:

Variable period of time (24-72 hours) is to be allowed for stabilization before surgical repair. Immediate respiratory support should be provided, including rapid endotracheal intubation and sedation. 

Bag and mask ventilation is contraindicated in newborns with congenital diaphragmatic hernia because it causes distension of the stomach which in turn may limit the expansion of the already hypoplastic lung.

During surgery, the viscera are reduced into the abdominal cavity, and the posterolateral defect in the diaphragm is closed using interrupted, nonabsorbable sutures. In most cases (80%-90%), a hernia sac is not present. If identified, it is excised at the time of repair.

Related Pearl: Congenital diaphragmatic hernias (CDH)

It is due to the failure of the closure of the pleuroperitoneal canal in the developing fetus (Normally the pleuroperitoneal cavities separate by 8-10 weeks of gestation). Left-sided hernias are more common(80%).

The two well-recognized congenital sites where abdominal viscera can herniate into the chest are:

  • The foramen of Morgagni: a hernia in the anteromedial part of the diaphragm with a defect between the sternal and costal attachments. The most commonly involved viscus is the transverse colon.
  • The foramen of Bochdalek: through the dome of the diaphragm posterolaterally

CDH causes pulmonary hypoplasia (bilateral) by compressing the developing lung. These lungs have smaller bronchi, with less bronchial branching and less alveolar surface area than lungs in normal infants. Pulmonary hypertension may also develop due to increased thickness of arteriolar smooth muscle and also by multiple local and systemic vasoactive factors.

Clinical features:

  • respiratory distress at birth
  • grunting respiration
  • chest retractions
  • dyspnea
  • cyanosis
  • scaphoid abdomen
  • decreased breath sounds along with bowel sound over the chest with CDH
  • shifting of heart sounds to the right (for left-sided CDH)

questions.text: Most common organ that herniates in Morgagni’s hernia is ______
questions.solution:
The transverse colon is the most common herniating structure in a Morgagni hernia.

Morgagni Hernia:

  • A hernia in the anterior part of the diaphragm with a defect between the sternal and costal attachments
  • The most commonly involved viscus is the transverse colon.

questions.text: What is not true regarding a Bochdalek hernia?

choices.text: Early respiratory distress leading to early diagnosis and treatment is a good prognostic sign
The contents of hernial sac commonly includes retroperitoneal fat, left kidney or spleen
The condition is diagnosed prenatally by ultrasonography.
Pericardial cyst is a differential diagnosis.

questions.solution:
Early respiratory distress, within 6 hours of birth, is thought to be a poor prognostic sign.

Features of a Bochdalek hernia:

  • Respiratory distress is a cardinal sign in infants with a congenital diaphragmatic hernia (CDH).
  • Early respiratory distress, within 6 hr after birth, is thought to be a poor prognostic sign.
  • Children with CDH may also have a scaphoid abdomen and increased chest wall diameter.
  • Bowel sounds may also be heard in the chest, with a bilateral decrease in breath sounds.
  • The point of maximal cardiac impulse may be displaced away from the side of a hernia if a mediastinal shift has occurred.
  • Retroperitoneal fat, left kidney, spleen or only the omentum commonly herniates through the defect. If the defect is large, most abdominal contents including stomach may herniate.

Diagnosis:

  • Chest radiography and passage of a nasal gastric tube confirm the diagnosis.
  • CDH can be diagnosed on prenatal ultrasonography (between 16 and 24 weeks of gestation)
  • High-speed fetal magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) can further define the lesion.

Ultrasonography findings:

  • Polyhydramnios
  • Chest mass
  • Mediastinal shift
  • Gastric bubble or a liver in the thoracic cavity
  • Fetal hydrops

Differential diagnosis:

  • Eventration
  • Cystic lung lesion (pulmonary sequestration or cystic adenomatoid Malformation)
  • Group B streptococcal sepsis: associated with delayed onset of symptoms and a CDH often on the right side.
  • Pneumothorax: always occurs on contralateral to the side of CDH.

Treatment:

Variable period of time (24-72 hours) to allow for stabilization before surgical repair

The viscera are reduced into the abdominal cavity, and the posterolateral defect in the diaphragm is closed using interrupted, nonabsorbable sutures.

In most cases (80%-90%), a hernia sac is not present. If identified, it is excised at the time of repair.

Conventional mechanical ventilation, high-frequency oscillatory ventilation (HFOV), and extracorporeal membrane oxygenation (ECMO) are the 3 main strategies to support respiratory failure in the newborn with CDH.

Good relative indicators of stability are as follows:

  • Requirement for conventional ventilation only
  • Low peak inspiratory pressure
  • Fio2 <50

If the defect is too large, a porous polytetrafluoroethylene (Gore-Tex) patch is used.

questions.text: Which of the following is the most common Gastrointestinal atresia?
questions.solution:
The most common Gastrointestinal atresia is duodenal atresia (60%) followed by jejunal and ileal atresia (20%). Colonic atresia is the least common type (7-10%).

Duodenal atresias are commonly associated with chromosomal abnormalities such as Down syndrome. It occurs approximately in 1/10,000 births.

questions.text: A 3-day-old neonate presented with recurrent bilious vomiting. An X-ray erect abdomen is given below. What is the next best step in managing this condition?
questions.solution:
Explanation: 

The given clinical history with an x-ray showing a triple bubble sign is suggestive of jejunal atresia. The next best step is to perform a contrast study to localize the site of obstruction.

Small bowel atresias present with intestinal obstruction soon after birth.             

  • Bilious vomiting is the dominant feature in jejunal atresia 
  • Abdominal distension is more prominent in ileal atresia

A small amount of pale meconium may be passed, despite the atresia.

Plain abdomen radiographs in a jejunal/ileal atresia case will show multiple air-fluid levels and dilated loops. They don't reliably distinguish small and large bowels in neonates and hence contrast studies are often required to localize the obstruction.

Water-soluble enemas (Gastrogaffin, Hypaque) are particularly useful in differentiating atresia from meconium ileus and Hirschsprung disease. Contrast studies also help to rule out distal intestinal obstruction and occasionally may act therapeutically to relieve obstructions.

In most cases of jejunal/ileal atresia, the distal end of the dilated proximal small bowel is resected and a primary end-to-end anastomosis is done. If the proximal bowel is extremely dilated, it may need to be tapered to the distal bowel before anastomosis.

Other options: 

Option A:  CT is not recommended for neonates owing to the harmful effects of radiation.

Option C: USG abdomen does not help to localize the site of obstruction and is more useful in the diagnosis of intussusception, where there is an abdominal mass.

Option D: Explorative laparotomy is not done for diagnosing intestinal atresias. 

Related Pearl: Radiological findings in various GI disorders

Duodenal atresia: Double bubble sign

 

Jejunal and ileal atresia: Multiple air-fluid levels (plain erect X-ray abdomen) presenting as triple bubble sign. 

 

Congenital hypertrophic pyloric stenosis: Single enlarged gastric gas bubble - single bubble sign

 

Sigmoid volvulus: Coffee bean sign 

 

Achalasia cardia: Bird-beak sign

 

Small bowel obstruction: The obstructed bowel loops are central in location and show valvulae conniventes (mucosal folds that cross the entire diameter of the bowel) characteristic of jejunal involvement.

Large bowel obstruction: The presence of haustrations is a feature of large bowel obstruction. Haustral folds are irregular and do not cross the entire diameter of the bowel. These are absent in the caecum. 

 

Caecal volvulus: Presence of caecal dilatation, single air-fluid level extending into the left upper quadrant, and absence of gas in the distal colon. The colonic haustrations are well maintained.

 

Midgut volvulus: Corkscrew appearance showing the duodenum and jejunum spiraling around the mesenteric vessels in upper GI contrast studies.

 

Necrotizing enterocolitis (NEC): Abdominal X-ray findings include pneumatosis intestinalis (air in the bowel wall).

Cystic fibrosis (CF): Abdominal x-ray with contrast enema reveals a microcolon with several meconium plugs.

questions.text: Bishop-Koop anastomosis is done for which of the following conditions?
questions.solution:
Bishop-Koop Anastomosis and Mikulicz enterostomy are done for meconium ileus.

Meconium ileus (also known as DIOS - Distal Intestinal Obstructive Syndrome) is defined as intestinal obstruction due to inspissated meconium within the terminal ileum. 

In the Bishop-Koop procedure, the proximal distended limb is joined to the side of the distal small bowel. This is vented by a 'chimney' to the abdominal wall. The Bishop–Koop operation with its irrigating stoma is now only rarely used.

  • Ramstedt pyloromyotomy is the standard operation for hypertrophic pyloric stenosis.
  • Kasai procedure is done for biliary atresia.
  • Duhamel, Soave, Swenson procedures are done in Hirschsprung’s disease.

questions.text: An infant presents with copious bilious vomiting and abdominal distension on the 5th day of life. He had not passed meconium for the first 3 days after birth. An abdominal radiograph shows the presence of dilated bowel loops. What is the gold standard investigation for the given condition?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario is suggestive of Hirschsprung's disease. A rectal biopsy is the gold standard for the diagnosis of Hirschsprung’s disease.

A rectal biopsy 2 cm above the dentate line is the ideal area for a biopsy.

Hirschsprung’s disease is a developmental disorder characterized by the absence of ganglion cells in the myenteric (Auerbach) plexus and submucosal (Meissner) plexus. Most infants present with abdominal distention and bilious emesis with failure to pass meconium within the first 24 hours of life.

The initial investigation is a contrast enema. The area between the dilated and contracted segments is referred to as the transition zone. The affected part shows the absence of ganglion cells and hypertrophy of nerve trunks in the rectal biopsy.

Other investigations for Hirschsprung’s disease include:

  • Water-soluble contrast enema - shows the presence of contracted aganglionic rectum, transition zone, and a dilated normally innervated colon.
  • Anorectal manometry - shows the failure of the relaxation of the internal anal sphincter.

 Definitive surgeries for Hirschsprung disease are as follows:

  • Swenson procedure, where aganglionic bowel is removed and a coloanal anastomosis is performed.
  • Duhamel procedure, where the aganglionic rectal stump is left in place and the ganglionated normal colon is pulled posterior.
  • Soave procedure, where endorectal mucosal dissection is done within the aganglionic distal rectum. The ganglionated normal colon is pulled through the remnant muscular cuff, and a coloanal anastomosis is performed.

questions.text: A 2-year-old child is brought to the casualty with severe abdominal pain. On performing emergency exploratory laparotomy, the following finding is noted. Which of the following statements is false regarding this condition?

choices.text: Can be a lead point for intussusception
The most common presenting symptom is bleeding in younger children
It is a false diverticulum which extends from the anti-mesenteric side
Most common heterotopic tissue is gastric mucosa

questions.solution:
Meckel’s diverticulum is a true diverticulum, which extends from the antimesenteric side of the small bowel. The diverticula which contain all the layers of the intestine are called true diverticula. 

Meckel’s diverticulum is caused by a failure of normal regression of the vitelline duct that develops during weeks 5-7 of gestation.

The rule of 2's (Mnemonic for Meckel’s diverticulum) :

  • 2 types of heterotopic mucosa (gastric & pancreatic)
  • 2% incidence
  • located within 2 feet of the ileocecal valve
  • approximately 2 inches in length
  • Usually symptomatic by 2 years of age

The most common presentation is painless, massive, lower GI bleed in children younger than 5 years. Meckel's diverticulum can be the lead point for ileoileal or ileocolic intussusception.

A bleeding Meckel's diverticulum may be confirmed by a 99 mTc-pertechnetate isotope scan to detect ectopic gastric mucosa. 

Surgical treatment is the definitive therapy for Meckel’s diverticulum. A simple V-shaped diverticulectomy with transverse closure of the ileum is the ideal surgical approach.

questions.text: A surgery resident is examining a child born with the following defect. Which of the following statements regarding this defect is false?

choices.text: The central defect of the abdominal wall may be more than 4 cm
This defect is usually not associated with other congenital anomalies
The overlying sac is made of amnion and peritoneum
This defect is a component of the Cantrell's pentalogy

questions.solution:
Omphalocele is usually associated with other congenital anomalies whereas gastroschisis is rarely associated with other congenital anomalies.

Omphalocele refers to a congenital defect of the abdominal wall in which the bowel and solid viscera are covered by the peritoneum and amniotic membrane.

  • During normal development of the human embryo, the midgut herniates outward through the umbilical ring and continues to grow. 
  • Between 10th-12th week of gestation, the midgut returns to the coelomic cavity and undergoes proper rotation and fixation, along with the closure of the umbilical ring. 
  • If the intestine fails to return, the infant is born with the abdominal contents protruding directly through the umbilical ring, with an intact sac covering the abdominal viscera, termed an omphalocele.

The sac is composed of an outer layer of amnion and an inner layer of peritoneum. It is seen in omphalocele and not in gastroschisis. Omphalocele can vary from a small defect with intestinal contents to a giant omphalocele in which the abdominal wall defect measures 4 cm or more in diameter. It may even contain liver.

Omphalocele occurs in association with special syndromes such as:

  • There is a 60% to 70% incidence of associated anomalies, especially cardiac anomalies (20–40% of cases) and chromosomal abnormalities.
  • Exstrophy of the cloaca (vesicointestinal fissure)
  • The Beckwith-Wiedemann constellation of anomalies (macroglossia, macrosomia, hypoglycemia, and visceromegaly and omphalocele)
  • The Cantrell’s pentalogy (lower thoracic wall malformations like cleft sternum, ectopia cordis, epigastric omphalocele, anterior midline diaphragmatic hernia, and cardiac anomalies).

Related Pearl: Difference between gastroschisis and omphalocele

Defect size (diameter) 2-3 cm 2-15 cm
Sac Never Always, may be ruptured
Gestational age Prematurity Term
Umbilical cord Adjacent to the defect (defect is seen usually on its right side)  Attached to sac
Herniated viscera Small bowel, stomach, colon Small bowel, stomach, colon, liver
Malrotation Yes Yes
Bowel character Inflammatory, edematous Normal
Enternal nutrition Delayed Normal
Associated abnormalities Uncommon (10% atresia) Common (50%)

questions.text: A 19-year-old lady delivered a neonate with the following defect. Which of the following statements about the defect is false?

choices.text: The defect is generally located to the right of the umbilical cord
Herniation of liver is commonly associated with this condition
The incidence of this defect is more in preterm babies
Serial reduction of eviscerated intestines maybe done for management

questions.solution:
The above image shows gastroschisis. Herniation of the liver is more commonly seen with omphalocele than gastroschisis.

Gastroschisis represents a congenital anomaly characterized by a defect in the anterior abdominal wall. The abdominal contents protrude through this defect. It is the most common anomaly seen in babies born to mothers under 20 years of age. Unlike omphalocele, there is no overlying sac and the size of the defect is usually <4 cm.

An orogastric tube is placed to decompress the stomach. For primary closure, bowel loops are reduced, fascia and skin are approximated.

If the viscera cannot be reduced into the abdomen, a silo is placed at the bedside as shown in the image. The eviscerated intestines are reduced serially during 5 to 7 days, followed by operative fascial closure.

Related Pearl: Difference between gastroschisis and omphalocele

questions.text: The most common extracranial solid tumour in infants and children is  _______.
questions.solution:
Neuroblastoma is the most common extracranial solid tumour of childhood. While brain tumours are the most common solid tumour of childhood.

Neuroblastoma is a malignancy of neuroblast cells in the adrenal medulla or sympathetic ganglia and typically presents as an abdominal or paravertebral mass. Raccoon eyes (periorbital ecchymoses) are seen in neuroblastoma due to orbital metastasis. 

Shimada classification is used for classifying neuroblastoma.

Blue subcutaneous nodules represent skin dissemination of tumour and are associated with the blueberry muffin syndrome.

questions.text: The most common site of rhabdomyosarcoma in children is _______.
questions.solution:
The most common site of rhabdomyosarcoma in children is the head and neck.

Rhabdomyosarcoma is the most common pediatric soft tissue sarcoma and accounts for approximately 3.5% of childhood cancers.

These tumours may occur at virtually any anatomic site but are usually found in the head and neck (25%), genitourinary tract (24%), extremities (19%) and orbit (9%). Retroperitoneum and other sites account for the remainder of primary sites.

Rhabdomyosarcomas are the most common soft tissue tumors among children younger than 15 years and can occur at any site comprised of striated muscle.

Rhabdomyosarcoma is classified into three types - embryonal, alveolar, and pleomorphic. Embryonal rhabdomyosarcoma is the most common type.

questions.text: The most common malignant brain tumor in children is ________.
questions.solution:
Medulloblastoma is the most common malignant brain tumour in children.

They are usually midline. Most of them occur in the cerebellum and present with symptoms of increased ICP. 

Most common tumours in children:

  • Brain tumours are the most common solid tumours.
  • Pilocytic astrocytoma is the most common brain tumour (usually not malignant).
  • Neuroblastoma is the most common extracranial solid tumour.
  • Rhabdomyosarcomas are the most common soft tissue tumours.

Related Pearl: Most commons of Brain tumours

Most common tumor of the brain - Metastasis secondary to lungs > breast

Most common primary CNS tumor - glioma > meningioma

Most common primary CNS tumor in children - pilocytic astrocytoma

Most common primary CNS tumor in adults - astrocytoma

Most common primary malignant tumor of the brain in children - medulloblastoma

Most common primary malignant tumor of the brain in adults - glioblastoma

questions.text: A female baby born at 30 weeks of gestation was admitted to NICU for prematurity and respiratory distress. She was placed on CPAP and enteric feeds were started. On day 5 of admission, she became lethargic and there was distension of the abdomen. A plain radiograph of the abdomen shows the following findings. Which statement about the condition is false?

choices.text: Antenatal steroids have shown to reduce the occurrence of this condition
Modified Bell's staging can be used for this condition
Surgery is the treatment of choice for all stages

questions.solution:
The clinical scenario and radiological findings are indicative of necrotizing enterocolitis (NEC). The absolute indication for operative management of NEC is the presence of intestinal perforation. Milder cases can be treated with gut rest, antibiotics, and parenteral nutrition. 

The radiograph shows the presence of multiple air bubbles within the bowel wall. This is called pneumatosis intestinalis and is a pathognomonic sign suggestive of necrotizing enterocolitis. 

Necrotizing enterocolitis is the necrosis of a portion of the bowel and is the most common gastrointestinal surgical emergency in the neonatal period. The single most important risk factor is prematurity. Other contributing factors are enteral feeding, ischemia, and infection. Administration of antenatal steroids is known to reduce the occurrence of NEC.

It usually occurs in the first few days of life after the initiation of the enteral feeds. Some clinical features include:

  • Lethargy
  • Feeding intolerance
  • Bloody stools
  • Abdominal distension
  • Abdominal tenderness.

The radiograph may show pneumatosis intestinalis, portal venous gas, ascites, and the presence of free air.

The modified Bell's criteria is used for staging the severity of NEC.

questions.text: A 5-year-old child presents with jaundice and abdominal pain. On examination, there is a palpable mass in the right hypochondrium. MRCP reveals multiple dilatations limited to the intrahepatic bile ducts. Which of the following statements about this condition is false?

choices.text: Todani classification is used for this condition
This condition is also known as Caroli's disease
Central dot sign is a characteristic CT finding associated with this condition
Endoscopic sphincterotomy followed by surveillance is the treatment of choice

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of Caroli's disease (type V choledochal cyst). Liver transplantation is the preferred treatment of choice here.

Choledochal cysts are cystic dilations of the common bile duct (CBD). They present with a triad of jaundice, a palpable upper quadrant mass, and abdominal pain.

There are mainly five types of choledochal cysts. The original classification for choledochal cysts by Alonso–Lej, has been modified by Todani.

MRCP is the investigation of choice. The beaded appearance of intrahepatic bile ducts on HIDA scan and central dot sign on CT are characteristic findings associated with Caroli's disease. 

The arrows in the image given below are pointing to the central dot sign.

Related Pearl: Classification of Choledochal Cysts

Type

Feature

Type I

The most common choledochal cyst type; it involves only the extrahepatic biliary tree and is generally a fusiform dilation.

Type II

Saccular diverticulum off the common bile duct and may be mistaken for an accessory gallbladder.

Type III

A cystic dilation of the intramural common bile duct, within the wall of the duodenum, known as choledochoceles.

Type IV

Type IVa: Cysts involving the intrahepatic and extrahepatic biliary tree

Type IVb: Multiple cysts limited to the extrahepatic biliary tree.

Type V

Also known as Caroli disease, involve the intrahepatic ducts only.

questions.text: A 10-year-old child came with complaints of pain over the right lower quadrant and lower back pain. On examination, the patient had pain over the right side of the hip on passive extension with a mass in the right lumbar region pointing towards the groin. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical history of lower back pain, mass in the right lumbar region pointing towards the groin and pain on passive extension of the ipsilateral hip is suggestive of a psoas abscess. 

Psoas abscess is a retroperitoneal abscess, caused due to various etiologies. Previously, tuberculosis of the spine was the most common cause secondary to spreading infection from the digestive or urinary tract, which can cause psoas abscess. Nowadays, Crohn’s disease is the most common cause. Patients present with flank pain, fever and chills, malaise and weight loss. They can have referred pain to the hip, groin or knee. When the swelling extends across the groin and below the inguinal ligament along the course of the iliopsoas, it becomes cross fluctuant across the inguinal ligament.

Imaging is done by a CT scan, which shows a low-density mass with surrounding inflammation and infiltration of surrounding fat and gas or air-fluid levels.

Treatment is done by percutaneous CT-guided drainage and appropriate antibiotics.

Other options:

Option A: Pyelonephritis is usually associated with a history of urinary tract infection and sudden onset of pain in the flank and hypochondrium, not the lumbar region.

Option C: Appendicitis (retrocaecal) can present with pain on passive extension of the hip (psoas sign), but the presence of a mass in the right lumbar region pointing towards the groin makes it an unlikely diagnosis.

Option D: Testicular torsion is a surgical emergency condition presenting with sudden onset pain in the scrotum, groin and lower abdomen, tenderness, redness and edema of the scrotal skin.

questions.text: A 3-year child is brought to the pediatrician for the evaluation of the lateral neck mass. On examination, a painless, soft, fluctuating mass is found in the lateral side of the neck, as shown in the image. The slip sign is negative, and the swelling is brilliantly transilluminant. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A soft, painless, brilliantly transilluminant, fluctuating mass found in the posterior part of the neck in a child, is most likely to be a cystic hygroma.

Cystic hygroma is a lymph-filled sac that results from the obstruction of the lymph vessels during their development. It is most commonly present in the posterior triangle of the neck. The mass may be apparent at birth or may appear in early childhood due to the increased accumulation of lymph. Since the sac is filled with lymph, it is soft, fluctuating, and brilliantly transilluminant.

Treatment:

  • Aspiration of the contents, followed by excision once the sac or capsule gets thickened by fibrous tissue.
  • Single cysts can be treated with sclerosing therapy. Commonly used sclerosants include OK–432 or Picibanil, which is a mixture of group A Streptococcus pyogenes strain, pure ethanol, interferon alpha-2a, and doxycycline.
  • Complete excision is done in case of multiple cysts.

Option B: A branchial cleft cyst also presents as soft fluctuant swelling. It is present in the anterior neck and at the junction of the upper third and middle third of the sternocleidomastoid muscle.

Option C: Lipoma is less commonly seen in children. The swelling is non-fluctuant and when palpated, the edge slips under the finger. This is known as the slip sign.

Option D: Cervical lymphadenopathy is seen in children with infections of the parotid and upper respiratory tract infections. On palpation, they are firm and non-fluctuant.

questions.text: The most common location of cystic hygroma is ________.
questions.solution:
Cystic hygroma, also known as cystic lymphangioma and macrocystic lymphatic malformation, is a congenital multiloculated lymphatic lesion that can arise anywhere but is classically found in the left posterior triangle of the neck.

The other common sites are the axillary, mediastinal, inguinal, and retroperitoneal regions. It occurs as a result of sequestration or obstruction of developing lymph vessels. The cysts are lined by endothelium and filled with lymph.

questions.text: A 15-year-old girl presented with a slow-growing, rubbery, non-tender swelling on the side of the neck as shown in the image. Examination shows the presence of freckles and skin patches over the face and trunk. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A lateral neck mass in a pediatric patient, which is non-tender and present in association with freckles, and hyperpigmented skin patches (cafe-au-lait spots) is suggestive of neural tumor i.e. neurofibroma. 

Neurofibroma is a benign tumor arising from the connective tissue of the nerve containing ectodermal, neural and mesodermal connective tissue components. It can be single or multiple. It is the most common intradural extramedullary spinal tumor. Neurofibromas can be local, generalized (von Recklinghausen's disease) or plexiform types. Patients present with mild pain or a painless swelling usually in the subcutaneous or cutaneous plane with tingling, numbness and paraesthesia along the distribution of the nerve. Complications of neurofibroma include cystic degeneration, erosion into deeper planes, cord compression and paralysis (spinal neurofibroma) and sarcomatous changes.

Treatment is excision under general or regional anesthesia. Indications for surgery in neurofibroma include symptomatic patients (pain and pressure symptoms), cosmetic problems and malignant transformation (5%).

Option A: Cystic hygroma is a type of congenital lymphangioma. This swelling is soft and partially compressible, which shows positive fluctuation and translucency test.

Option B: Chemodectoma or carotid body tumor is a rare tumor, most commonly present in the fifth decade and there is an association with pheochromocytoma. These patients usually present with a slowly enlarging, painless lump at the carotid bifurcation.

Option D: A lipoma is a soft painless swelling. It shows the characteristic slip sign and is freely mobile.

questions.text: A  first-born, 5-weeks-old male infant presents with non-bilious projectile vomiting. The abdominal radiograph shows the following finding. Which of the following will be the preferred investigation in this case?
questions.solution:
The given clinical vignette and the radiographic image showing the presence of an enlarged gastric gas bubble (single bubble) are suggestive of congenital hypertrophic pyloric stenosis (CHPS). Ultrasound examination is the investigation of choice for this condition.

Congenital hypertrophic pyloric stenosis (CHPS) is characterized by abnormal thickening of the pylorus muscles in the stomach leading to gastric outlet obstruction. First-born male infants are at the highest risk.

Infants usually present with 

  • Projectile, non-bilious vomiting due to gastric outlet obstruction, most commonly between 3 and 6 weeks of age.
  • Olive-shaped mass palpable in the right upper quadrant or epigastrium.
  • Visible peristalsis after feeding, moving from left to right, followed by projectile vomiting.
  • Metabolic abnormalities include hypokalemic, hypochloremic, metabolic alkalosis with paradoxical aciduria.

Ultrasound examination confirms the diagnosis of congenital hypertrophic pyloric stenosis (CHPS) in the majority of cases. The diagnostic criteria for pyloric stenosis are a muscle thickness of ≥4 mm and a pyloric length of ≥16 mm.

Ultrasound signs seen in Congenital Hypertrophic Pyloric stenosis are:

  • Target sign (Hypoechoic thickened pyloric muscle with a hyperechoic central mucosa)
  • Cervix sign
  • Nipple sign.
  • Antral nipple sign

The child should be rehydrated and the metabolic abnormality has to be corrected before proceeding to surgery. The Ramstedt pyloromyotomy is the standard surgical procedure for its treatment.

The ultrasound image given above shows hypertrophied pylorus resembling that of the uterine cervix (cervix sign) and double-layered hypertrophic mucosa protruding into the stomach, (Nipple sign).

The ultrasound image given above shows redundant pyloric mucosa protruding into the antrum - Antral nipple sign.

Related Pearl: Radiological findings in various GI disorders

Duodenal atresia: Double bubble sign

 

Jejunal and ileal atresia: Multiple air-fluid levels (plain erect X-ray abdomen) presenting as triple bubble sign. 

 

Congenital hypertrophic pyloric stenosis: Single enlarged gastric gas bubble - single bubble sign

 

Sigmoid volvulus: Coffee bean sign 

 

Achalasia cardia: Bird-beak sign

 

Small bowel obstruction: The obstructed bowel loops are central in location and show valvulae conniventes (mucosal folds that cross the entire diameter of the bowel) characteristic of jejunal involvement.

Large bowel obstruction: The presence of haustrations is a feature of large bowel obstruction. Haustral folds are irregular and do not cross the entire diameter of the bowel. These are absent in the caecum. 

 

Caecal volvulus: Presence of caecal dilatation, single air-fluid level extending into the left upper quadrant, and absence of gas in the distal colon. The colonic haustrations are well maintained.

 

Midgut volvulus: Corkscrew appearance showing the duodenum and jejunum spiraling around the mesenteric vessels in upper GI contrast studies.

 

Necrotizing enterocolitis (NEC): Abdominal X-ray findings include pneumatosis intestinalis (air in the bowel wall).

Cystic fibrosis (CF): Abdominal x-ray with contrast enema reveals a microcolon with several meconium plugs.

questions.text: A 2-month-old baby is brought to the outpatient department for a facial defect. On examination, the following findings were noticed. The soft and the hard palate are intact. Which of the following is the most appropriate management in this child?

choices.text: Cleft lip repair at 9 to 12 months
Cleft lip repair at 4 to 6 months

questions.solution:
The given clinical image is that of a child with a cleft lip on the left side. The most appropriate management for this patient would be a cleft lip repair at 4-6 months.

Etiology of the cleft lip can include familial, protein and vitamin deficiency, rubella infection, radiation, chromosomal abnormalities, maternal epilepsy and drug intake during pregnancy (steroids/eptoin/diazepam)

Majority of the cases are unilateral and cleft lip alone is uncommon.

Millard Criteria (Rule of 10) is used to undertake surgery for cleft lip.

  • 10 pound in weight
  • 10 weeks old
  • 10g% Hemoglobin

Millard cleft lip repair by rotating the local nasolabial flaps is done.

The most appropriate management for this patient would be cleft lip repair at 4 to 6 months. 

According to Delaire timing of cleft surgery - unilateral cleft lip alone can be operated in one stage operation and is done at 4-6 months.

The different types of facial clefts are shown below:

  1. Unilateral cleft lip with alveolar involvement
  2. Bilateral cleft lip with alveolar involvement
  3. Unilateral cleft lip associated with cleft palate
  4. Bilateral cleft lip and palate
  5. Cleft palate only
